questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
1219 
Sold by @itachibot The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is 
substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as 
paralysis agitans. Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the 
synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the 
substantia nigra. Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of 
motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans. Other options: Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to 
damage to the substantia nigra. Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the 
entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe. Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition 
primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common gene mutation seen in patients with familial Parkinson's disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common form of monogenic familial PD is PARK8, caused by mutations in the 
leucine-rich repeat kinase-2 (LRRK2) gene. Familial forms of parkinsonism (designated PARK1 through PARK13) have been associated with 
causative mutations in a number of nuclear genes. A few of these are: • The LRRK2 gene mutation causes autosomal dominant PD (PARK8). In this condition, Middle 
to late-onset PD is seen, which resembles typical PD and is responsive to levodopa. • Mutations in alpha-synuclein (PARK 1 and PARK4) cause rare forms of familial PD and 
constitute the major component of Lewy bodies in sporadic PD. 1220 
Sold by @itachibot • Parkin-associated PD (PARK 2) & PINK1-associated PD (PARK6) are autosomal recessive 
seen in young-onset PD. • Mutation in the glucocerebrosidase gene (GBA) gene of Gauchers represents the most important 
risk factor for the development of Parkinson's disease. Patients with PD who are GBA mutation 
carriers have a younger age at onset.

questions.question:
Question 3: 1209 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following features would you not expect to see in patients with Parkinson’s 
disease?
questions.explanation:
Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are not a feature of Parkinson's disease. Cardinal motor features 
in PD include: • Resting tremors • Bradykinesia • Rigidity • Gait disturbance / postural instability Mnemonic: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability • Other motor features include: • Micrographia • Masked facies (hypomimia) • Reduced eye blinking • Soft voice (hypophonia) • Dysphagia • Non-motor features are: • Anosmia • Sensory disturbance (pain) • Mood Disorders (depression) • Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder) • Autonomic: • GI disturbances • Genitourinary disturbances • Sexual dysfunction • Orthostatic hypotension • Cognitive impairment Parkinson’s disease(PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's 
disease. UK Brain Bank criteria is used for the diagnosis of PD. 1221 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 66-year-old man presents with complaints of resting tremor in his right hand, which 
improves with movement. He also says that he has difficulty initiating movements and his 
wife says his movements have been slow. On examination, rigidity is observed to passive arm 
movement and shuffling gait with a stooped posture is noticed. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding the pathology of this condition?

options.a: Substantia nigra pars reticulata is unaffected by the disease process
options.b: Decreased striatal dopamine is seen in this condition
options.c: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta
options.d: Lewy bodies which containing degenerated tau protein are seen

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies seen in 
Parkinson's disease do not contain tau protein. They contain the protein -synuclein. Pathologic hallmarks of Parkinson's disease include: • Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) • Reduced striatal dopamine • Intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which contain the protein 
-synuclein

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with Parkinson's disease says that he cannot even hold a coffee mug properly due to 
tremors. What is the frequency of the tremors likely to be?
questions.explanation:
The frequency of resting tremors in Parkinson’s disease is 4–6 Hz. More than 70 percent of patients with Parkinson's disease have tremors as the presenting feature. 
The classic parkinsonian tremor begins as a low-frequency, pill-rolling motion of the fingers, 
progressing to forearm pronation/supination and elbow flexion/extension. Other features of the 
tremors are: • Typically asymmetric • Occurs at rest • Becomes less prominent with voluntary movement Frequency of various types of tremors: Physiological tremor (12 Hz ) > Essential tremor (8–10 
Hz) > Resting tremor in PD (4–6 Hz ).

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common psychiatric disturbance seen in patients with Parkinson's disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common psychiatric disturbance seen in Parkinson's disease is depression. The non-motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease include: • Cognitive dysfunction and subcortical dementia • Psychosis and hallucinations - Visual hallucinations are the most common psychotic symptom • Mood disorders: • Depression - most common psychiatric disturbance • Anxiety - second most common psychiatric disturbance • Abulia/apathy • Sleep disorders - insomnia, daytime sleepiness with sleep attacks, restless leg syndrome • Autonomic dysfunction 1222 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not an example of secondary parkinsonism?
questions.explanation:
Corticobasal syndrome is not an example of secondary parkinsonism. It s a type of Parkinson's 
plus syndrome. Causes of secondary Parkinsonism include: • Repeated head trauma—dementia pugilistica • Drug-induced • Tumor • Post-encephalitic PD • Toxins: manganese, MPTP, carbon monoxide, cyanide • Vascular • Liver failure

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common cause of secondary parkinsonism?
questions.explanation:
Dopamine-blocking agents such as neuroleptics are the most common cause of secondary 
parkinsonism. Causes of secondary Parkinsonism include: • Repeated head trauma—dementia pugilistica • Drug-induced • Tumor • Post-encephalitic PD • Toxins: manganese, MPTP, carbon monoxide, cyanide • Vascular • Liver failure

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented to the OPD with a shuffling gait, slowed movements and speech, and 
cogwheeling. He was started on a new drug recently. Which of the following drugs cannot 
cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of secondary parkinsonism. Bezatropine, also known as 
benztropine, is used in the treatment of parkinsonism. It does not cause secondary parkinsonism. Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic. It has been used for controlling tremors in 
drug-induced Parkinson's. Side effects include urinary dysfunction, glaucoma, and cognitive 
impairment. Drugs causing secondary parkinsonism: • Neuroleptics (typical antipsychotics) • Metoclopramide, chlorpromazine 1223 
Sold by @itachibot • Dopamine depleting agents (reserpine, tetrabenazine) • Calcium channel blocker: Flunnarizine, Cinnarizine • Lithium carbonate, amiodarone, -Methyldopa

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor?
questions.explanation: Benserazide is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor. Options B & D: Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl are centrally acting anticholinergic agents. Option C: Tetrabenazine is a dopamine depleting agent. It causes drug-induced Parkinsonism.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a non-ergot dopamine agonist?
questions.explanation: Apomorphine is a non-ergot dopamine agonist.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 75-year-old patient presents with an inability to move and speak. He has been experiencing 
increasing stiffness and slowness from the past 1 hour. He has an 8-year history of 
Parkinson's disease and takes his levodopa-carbidopa every day. The last dose was 4 hours 
back. What drug should be prescribed for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of a severe 'off' episode. The rescue agent for the 
treatment of severe 'off' episodes is apomorphine. Levodopa-induced motor complications consist of fluctuations in motor response ('on' episodes 
when the drug is working and 'off' episodes when parkinsonian features return) and involuntary 
movements are known as dyskinesias which typically complicate 'on' periods. Apomorphine is a non-ergot dopamine agonist. It has efficacy comparable to levodopa, but it must 
be administered parenterally (intravenous or subcutaneous) and has a very short half-life and 1224 
Sold by @itachibot duration of activity (45 min).

questions.question:
Question 14: 1212 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following drugs has disease-modifying action in Parkinson's disease?
questions.explanation:
Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor known to have some disease-modifying 
action in Parkinson's disease. Studies have shown that selegiline significantly delayed the time 
until the emergence of disability necessitating the introduction of levodopa in untreated PD 
patients. MAO-B inhibitors include: • Selegiline • Rasagiline (more potent) Cheese effect: inhibition of MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of tyramine in the gut, 
leading to a potentially fatal hypertensive reaction called the 'cheese effect'. It can be precipitated 
by tyramine-rich foods such as cheese, aged meat, and red wine. Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A isoform and are not associated with 
cheese effect in doses typically used in clinical practice.

questions.question: Question 16: All are true about levodopa-induced motor complications except:

options.a: More likely to occur in males
options.b: Seen in younger individuals with severe disease
options.c: Seen with higher doses of levodopa
options.d: Rhythmic movements that predominantly involve the lower extremities

questions.explanation:
Levodopa-induced motor complications are more likely to occur in females. 1225 
Sold by @itachibot The complications include transient, stereotypic, rhythmic movements that predominantly involve 
the lower extremities. It is seen in younger individuals with severe disease and also with higher 
doses of levodopa.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 65-year-old woman on treatment for Parkinson’s disease is brought to the OPD. Her 
husband is concerned because she has been shopping a lot and reached the maximum 
spending limit on 2 credit cards in the past week. She has also impulsively been buying 
several rabbits and raising them in their home. She admits feeling guilty after her purchases. 
Which of the following drugs is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of compulsive shopping. Pathological gambling, hypersexuality, 
and compulsive eating and shopping are the adverse effects of dopamine agonists. Levodopa can 
also cause these effects, but to a lesser extent than dopamine agonists.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with Parkinson's disease has been scheduled to undergo deep brain stimulation. 
What is the target site for this procedure?

options.a: Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus internus
options.b: Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus externus
options.c: Substantia nigra pars compacta and globus pallidus externus
options.d: Substantia nigra pars reticulata and globus pallidus internus

questions.explanation:
The target site for deep brain stimulation in Parkinson’s disease is the subthalamic nucleus (STN) 
and globus pallidus internus (GPi). It helps improve tremors and reduce both 'off' time and dyskinesia. It does not improve features 
that fail to respond to levodopa. It does not prevent the development or progression of 
non-dopaminergic features such as freezing, falling, and dementia.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is an example of Parkinson's plus syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Progressive supranuclear palsy is an example of Parkinson's plus syndrome. Parkinson's plus syndrome or atypical parkinsonism refers to a group of conditions that present 
with parkinsonism (rigidity and bradykinesia) but are different from PD due to underlying 
differences in clinical manifestations and pathology. They may have degeneration of the striatum, 
globus pallidus, cerebellum, and brainstem as well as the SNc. These include multiple system 
atrophy (MSA), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), and corticobasal syndrome (CBS). PSP is often misdiagnosed as Parkinson’s disease (PD). The substantia nigra is damaged in both 
diseases and this accounts for the overlapping symptoms which are observed. In PSP, 
impairment of cognitive functions occurs before the motor or ocular signs and this serves as an 
important distinguishing feature. Immunohistochemistry broadly classifies them into two subtypes: synucleopathies and 
tauopathies.

questions.question: Question 20: Which among the following features is not expected in a patient with atypical parkinsonism?

options.c: Poor or no response to levodopa

questions.explanation:
Early speech and gait impairment are seen in atypical parkinsonism. Features of atypical parkinsonism include: • Early speech and gait impairment 1226 
Sold by @itachibot • Absence of rest tremor • No motor asymmetry • Poor or no response to levodopa • Aggressive clinical course • Symptoms of severe early autonomic involvement • Early severe dementia also points towards atypical parkinsonism

questions.question:
Question 21: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonism and cerebellar features. MRI showed the 
finding as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis? 1214 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Parkinsonism, cerebellar features, and the 'hot cross bun' sign on MRI suggest multiple system 
atrophy (MSA). MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on 
predominant clinical features it is further divided into : • MSA-P: • Predominantly parkinsonian features are seen • T2 weighted MRI demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim • MSA-C: • Predominantly cerebellar features are seen • MRI shows cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

questions.question:
Question 22: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia 
except:
questions.explanation:
Orthostatic hypotension is not a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD) as per DSM-5. LBD also known as dementia with Lewy bodies is the second most type of progressive dementia 
after Alzheimer’s disease. Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, deposit in nerve cells in the brain 
region involved in thinking, memory, and movement (motor control) Core features of LBD as per DSM-5 are fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness, recurrent visual 
hallucination, and Parkinsonian symptoms. Suggestive features are REM sleep behavior disorder 
and severe neuroleptic sensitivity. Orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, and constipation are other features of LBD. Treatment of LBD includes rivastigmine and donepezil which may improve cognition, and reduce 
hallucinosis and delusion. Pimavanserin may be used to treat psychosis.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonian features which is unresponsive to levodopa. 
MRI image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? 1215 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
1227 
Sold by @itachibot An elderly male with a history of features of Parkinsonism nonresponsive to levodopa should raise 
suspicion for Parkinson plus syndromes which include progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), also known as the Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, 
is a tauopathy and is considered a neurodegenerative disease with no current efficacious 
treatment. It is characterized by decreased cognition, abnormal eye movements (supranuclear 
vertical gaze palsy), postural instability and falls, as well as parkinsonian features and speech 
disturbances. The atrophy of the midbrain results in hummingbird sign of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane). 
The preserved pons form the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain, the head, with beak 
extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasm. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with the 
reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio. Mickey mouse appearance, which is the reduction of anteroposterior midline midbrain diameter, 
at the level of the superior colliculi is seen on axial imaging. The following image shows the hummingbird sign: According to a recent imaging study data, the insula and frontal cortex seem to be involved in the 
development of anxiety in adults with Parkinson's disease.

questions.question:
Question 24: An 8-year-old girl exhibits rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary 
movements. What is this finding?
questions.explanation:
Rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements are seen in chorea. Sydenham's chorea (also called St. Vitus's dance) is a type of chorea that is typically seen in 
childhood (5-15 years) with prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection and is thought to be 
autoimmune in nature. It is characterized by the acute onset of choreiform movements and 
behavioral disturbances and is self-limiting. 1228

questions.question:
Question 25: During rounds, you see that a patient diagnosed with stroke exhibits wild, flinging 
movements on his right side. Where is the lesion likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral wild, flinging movements are called hemiballismus and is seen due to a lesion in the 
subthalamic nucleus. The most common cause of hemiballismus is stroke.

questions.question: Question 26: What is the most common acute drug-induced movement disorder?
questions.explanation:
The most common acute drug-induced movement disorder is dystonia. Drug-induced movement disorders are primarily associated with drugs that block dopamine 
receptors(neuroleptics) or central dopaminergic transmission. Neuroleptics are the 
commonest cause of this condition. Drug-induced movement disorders are classified as: • Acute: Dystonia is the most common acute hyperkinetic drug reaction; generalized in children, 
focal in adults. • Subacute: Akathisia is the commonest reaction in this category • Tardive syndromes: Develop after months to years of initiation of the drug. 1229 
Sold by @itachibot • Tardive dyskinesia is the most common. Choreiform movements affecting the mouth, lips, and 
tongue are seen. In severe cases, trunks, limbs, and respiratory muscles may also be affected. • In one third, TD remits within 3 months of stopping the drug and improvement occur over 
several years.

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is the most common movement disorder?
questions.explanation:
The most common movement disorder is essential tremor. It can present in childhood but dramatically increases in prevalence over the age of 70 years. 
Essential tremor is characterized by a high-frequency tremor 6-10 Hz that predominantly affects 
the upper extremities. The tremor is characteristically improved by alcohol and worsened by stress. Essential trem

questions.question:
Question 28: A 65-year-old man presents with a tremor in both hands that worsens when he is trying to eat 
or write something. He says that it gets worse when he is stressed and reduces when he 
drinks wine. His father also had similar symptoms. On examination, there are no resting 
tremors. Which of the following drugs can be used to control this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of essential tremor. It can be controlled by primidone. The drugs used to treat essential tremors are: • Beta-blockers: propranolol, atenolol • Anticonvulsants: • Primidone • Gabapentine • Topiramate In severe and drug-resistant cases, surgical treatment involves targeting the ventral intermediate 
(VIM) nucleus of the thalamus.

questions.question:
Question 30: A patient with a family history of Huntington's disease has come for genetic counselling. All 
of the following are true about this condition, except:

options.c: Westphal akinetic variant has good prognosis

questions.explanation:
Westphal akinetic variant has the worst prognosis. Huntington's disease shows an autosomal dominant inheritance. It is a trinucleotide repeat 
expansion disease with multiple CAG repeats (>40 repeats) in the coding region of the 
huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. It demonstrates genetic anticipation with earlier onset if 
inherited from the father. It presents in the second to third decade of life with cognitive impairment as an early feature. The 
dominant cognitive feature of HD is executive dysfunction. Additionally, dementia is seen later as 
the disease progresses. Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia. Decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to 
chorea. Treatment consists of haloperidol, tetrabenazine (Dopamine depletor). The following image shows MRI showing dilated ventricles (ex vacuo ventriculomegaly)- due to 
atrophy of caudate and putamen: 1231 
Sold by @itachibot MRI showing atrophy of caudate and putamen

questions.question: Question 31: St. Vitus' dance is the other name for which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Sydenham's chorea was originally called St. Vitus's dance. Sydenham's chorea is more common in females. It is typically seen in childhood (5-1 5 years) with 
prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection and is thought to be autoimmune in nature. It is characterized by the acute onset of choreiform movements and behavioral disturbances. It is self limited.Treatment is generally restricted to those with severe chorea.The chorea generally 
responds to dopamine-blocking agents, valproic acid, and carbamazepine.

questions.question: Question 32: All of the following features can be seen in patients with restless leg syndrome, except:
questions.explanation:
In restless leg syndrome (RLS), symptoms begin or worsen with rest. It is also called as 
Willis-Ekbom disease. The four core symptoms required for the diagnosis of RLS are: • An urge to move the legs • Usually caused or accompanied by an unpleasant sensation in the legs (creepy-crawly feeling, 
paresthesia, or burning) • Symptoms that begin or worsen with rest and partial or complete relief by movement • Worsening during the evening or night Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during 
rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated 
with burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic 1232 
Sold by @itachibot hypofunction is postulated. In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating 
factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, 
gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, 
ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term 
augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders. FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: • Gabapentin • Ropinirole • Pramipexole • Rotigotine A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from 
gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of 
moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a 
history of substance use disorder. Non-pharmacological treatments that can be used in restless leg syndrome are: • Avoiding alcohol at bedtime • Massaging affected legs • Hot baths • Applying hot or cold to the affected area • Engaging in moderate exercises 1233 
Sold by @itachibot ALS and Other Motor Neuron Diseases
